Description: Terracotta figure of Harpocrates, riding on goose. Harpokrates, astride a goose which walks to right. The god is naked except for an end of a himation coming from behind to cover his lower right leg. But for a side-lock, his head is shaven; he has a ribbon tied round his upper brow, with lotus buds on top of his head. His finger is to his mouth and he carries the Club of Herakles upright in his left hand against his left side. The goose is garlanded upon its chest. The back is plain, with a central circular vent, roughly pierced. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close, probably from the same mould-series: Christie’s South Kensington Sale Catalogue, 29 October 2003: lot 231; Dunand 1990: no. 191, dated Roman period; Fjeldhagen 1995: no. 19, dated first century ad; Kaufmann 1913: fig. 35:13; Török 1995: no. 85. Near: Breccia 1926: pl. lxxi:5, from Theadelphia; Breccia 1934: no. 127 = Iride Pasquali 1995: pl. lxxi:3; Christie’s South Kensington Sale Catalogue, 29 October 2003: lot 231; Dunand 1979: no. 222 = Grimm and Johannes 1975: pl. 106 = LIMC iv (2): pl. 261, Harpokrates 336b; Ewigleben and von Grumbkow 1991: no. 26 = LIMC iv (2): pl. 261, Harpokrates 336a, dated second half of second century ad; Fischer 1994: no. 617, from Alexandria, dated first half to middle of second century ad = Vogt 1924: pl. xiv:2; Török 1995: no. 84; Weber 1914: no. 99, said to be from the Fayum. Bibliog. Fischer 1994: 277 and 278, no. 617.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3073)
Condition: The group is broken away below the knees of the bird.
